  • Description: Shipment was discovered during sort operations. Inner contents: 2 cans of Easy Off Oven Cleaner @ 14.5 ounces, 1 can of Pam Cooking Oil @ 12 ounces. No Release (UN 1950 Aerosols Flammable, Class 2.1) No Release. There were also various cans of food, refried beans, glass jar of peppers all contained in a clear plastic tote held together with blue masking tape. No release. Held for FAA investigation.

  • Description: On July 10, 2025, one (1) 5-gallon pail of paint was damaged in a load shift and released approximately less than one (<1) gallon of paint to the trailer interior, dock floor, and pallet. R+L Carriers retained Cura Emergency Services, LC who dispatched a crew from Lone Star Hazmat (LSH) to remediate the site. The crew utilized hand tools to scrape the paint off of the impacted surfaces. All impacted materials and the damaged pail of paint were collected and containerized in two (2) 55-gallon drums.

  • Description: On July 2, 2025, two (2) 5-gallon pails of paint were forked and released approximately ten (10) gallons of paint to the dock floor. R+L Carriers retained Cura Emergency Services, LC who dispatched a crew from Lone Star Hazmat (LSH) to remediate the site. LSH personnel deployed granular absorbents to the paint-impacted dock floor and swept them in with hand tools. All spent absorbents and the two (2) 5-gallon damaged pails of paint were collected and containerized into one (1) 55-gallon drum.

item.description:
Report X-2025070129

Identified by scraper @ 2025-07-23T00:58:10+00:00

  • Incident Date: 2025-07-01
  • City: WAXAHACHIE
  • State: TX
  • Report Type: A hazardous material incident
  • Mode Of Transportation: Highway
  • Carrier/Reporter: ABF FREIGHT SYSTEM, INC.
  • Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Hazmat Injuries: 0
  • Non-Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Total Amount Of Damages: 0
  • Serious Incident Ind: No
  • Description: ABF stated in transit when making his delivery a piece of metal next to pro 219295566 fell over and punctured the 55 gallon drum of hazmat. ABF stated roughly 10 gallons has released onto the trailer floor and the customers lot. LSH personnel arrived and assessed the site. Crews located trailer 400 507 and observed an estimated twenty five (25) gallon release of ENECRETE DuraQuartz Resin Base to the trailer floor and gravel below the trailer. Crews deployed granular absorbents to the released material inside of the trailer and pavement, and used hand tools to dig the impacted gravel and collec t the spent absorbents. All spent absorbents were collected and containerized in one (1) 55-gallon drum for disposal by LSH personnel. After receiving approval from CES and the driver, crews secured the scene and demobilized.

  • City: ARLINGTON

  • Total Amount Of Damages: 0
  • Serious Incident Ind: No
  • Description: ONE GROUND HAZMAT PACKAGE MARKED NON-SPILLABLE BATTERY WAS PLACED IN A CARBOARD TOTE AND SENT DOWN THE CHUTE. WHILE TRAVELING IN THE TOTE THE BATTERY TERMINALS BEGAN TO BECOME EXPOSED AND SPARK. A SMALL FIRE BEGAN TO IGNITE. A MEMBER OF THE TEAM QUICKLY EXTINGUISHED THE FIRE AND MOVED ALL PACKAGES WITHIN THE TOTE OUTSIDE THE BUILDING. THE SMOKE DID IGNITE ALARMS CAUSING SIXTEEN EMPLOYEES TO BE EVACUATED FROM THE FACILITY FOR SEVEN TO EIGHT MINUTES. NO OUTSIDE AGENCIES WERE CONTACTED. NO INJURIES WERE NOTED.

  • City: WYLIE

  • Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Hazmat Injuries: 0
  • Non-Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Total Amount Of Damages: 7500
  • Serious Incident Ind: No
  • Description: E3 Environmental was dispatched to the site. Upon the contractors arrival, personnel observed that the released material impacted an area measuring approximately 3ft-by-3ft of the trailer floor and the concrete directly under the trailer and estimated that five (5) gallons of material was released due to a load shift that damaged six (6) 5-gallon plastic pails. E3 Environmental personnel deployed granular absorbents to the impacted areas and collected the spent absorbents and placed them into one (1) 55-gallon poly drum. The damaged pails were overpacked into one (1) additional 55-gallon poly drum. The two (2) drums were transported offsite for disposal.

  • City: IRVING
  • State: TX
  • Report Type: A hazardous material incident
  • Mode Of Transportation: Air
  • Carrier/Reporter: FEDERAL EXPRESS CORPORATION
  • Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Hazmat Injuries: 0
  • Non-Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Total Amount Of Damages: 0
  • Serious Incident Ind: No
  • Description: At approximately 7:15AM Central on 6/24/2025, FedEx Dangerous Goods Administration received a call from destination station in Dallas, TX for a dangerous goods spill with tracking 882234574549. The package had multiple containers and was declared as an All Packed in One fibreboard box containing UN1263 Paint Related Material and UN3470 Paint Related Material, Corrosive, Flammable. The specific product that spilled was CAAPCOAT PUT-10 Polyurethane Thinner, which the SDS confirmed was the UN1263 Paint Related Material. A single 1L glass container spilled from a broken closure of the bottle, spilling about 75mL of liquid.. The spill was contained by the dangerous goods spill cleanup specialist and held for pickup by the recipient.

item.description:
Report E-2025070187

Identified by scraper @ 2025-07-23T00:58:10+00:00

  • Incident Date: 2025-06-17
  • City: JACKSONVILLE
  • State: TX
  • Report Type: A hazardous material incident
  • Mode Of Transportation: Highway
  • Carrier/Reporter: LANGER TRANSPORT CORP.
  • Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Hazmat Injuries: 0
  • Non-Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Total Amount Of Damages: 0
  • Serious Incident Ind: No
  • Description: Our driver delivered a bulk load of Butyl Cellosolve Solvent to Axalta Coatings in Jacksonville, Texas. The driver used his pump and hoses to offload the shipment from our tank trailer into the customers storage tank. During the unloading process a leak developed due to an undetected cut in one of our discharge hoses and product poured onto the ground. Our driver immediately shut the interval on the trailer contained the spill. The customer then cleaned used an in house crew to clean up the material the was on the ground. The driver used a different hose and offloaded the rest of the product that was in the trailer. The hose that failed was previously inspected by our shop and showed no signs of any defects. The hose failed because there was an undetected cut in it. When the driver returned back to the terminal the hose was inspected and discarded. We have spoken to the driver and asked him to make sure that he inspects his hoses more thoroughly.

item.title: Report X-2025061340
item.description:
Report X-2025061340

Identified by scraper @ 2025-07-23T00:58:10+00:00

  • Incident Date: 2025-06-16
  • City: LA FERIA
  • State: TX
  • Report Type: A hazardous material incident
  • Mode Of Transportation: Highway
  • Carrier/Reporter: ABF FREIGHT SYSTEM, INC.
  • Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Hazmat Injuries: 0
  • Non-Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Total Amount Of Damages: 0
  • Serious Incident Ind: No
  • Description: Two pails arrived crushed from freight shift to 129 from Dallas. One of the pails was empty by the time they arrived. The operations supervisor advised that the pails were creased and did not appear to be damaged from a forklift strike so he was sure it was from the load shift. The operations superv isor also advised that the damaged pails were UN1866. Safety advised CURA would be contacted for remediation. Crews proceeded to unload the trailer, downstack the impacted pallet, and they observed a total two of (2) 5-gallon pails of resin solution (UN1866) had been damaged, so crews removed them f or waste. E3 personnel deployed granular absorbents to the released product in the trailer and swept them in with hand tools. Crews wiped down the impacted freight, pallet, and trailer with absorbent pads and cleaning agents, and restacked the undamaged freight for further shipment and processing. A ll spent absorbents and any miscellaneous cleanup debris were collected and containerized into one (1) 55-gallon drum, and the damaged pails were all collected and containerized into one (1) other 55-gallon drum. Both drums of waste were labeled appropriately and staged in the terminal's waste holdi ng room.

  • Description: At 16:09 ET, XPO notified the Call Center of a cargo release at a customer location in Lampasas, TX. It was reported that approximately 6 gallons of Acid Magic Multi-Use Formula released from one 275-gallon tote due to unknown reasons. The release impacted trailer #4355071. No storm drains or waterways are reported to be impacted by the release. Contractors arrived onsite and confirmed approximately 15-gallons of UN1760 Acid Magic Multi-Use Formula product released to entire wooden trailer floor and 15x4 gravel area due to punctured by other freight. The tote was transferred and then cut up and put in (3) 55-gallon poly drums containing impacted debris, PPE and cut-up tote pieces. The waste was taken to the terminal and staged onsite for terminal personnel to manage.

item.description:
Report I-2025060066

Identified by scraper @ 2025-07-23T00:58:10+00:00

  • Incident Date: 2024-12-09
  • City: CENTER
  • State: TX
  • Report Type: A hazardous material incident
  • Mode Of Transportation: Highway
  • Carrier/Reporter: Central Arkansas Petroleum Transport, Inc
  • Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Hazmat Injuries: 0
  • Non-Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Total Amount Of Damages: 35593
  • Serious Incident Ind: Yes
  • Description: On December 9th, 2024, at approximately 1700, Tyson began refueling procedures for the above ground storage tank. The receiving tank began to overfill due to operator error. Immediately, the Tyson spill response team started laying down absorbent socks around the storm drain and then poured a load of chicken feed to act as an absorbent / berm around the affected area. The diesel fuel was contained on the concrete, but approximately 50 gallons of fuel was in the rock bed surrounding the fuel tank. A hazardous response team (Hopkins Wrecker Service) was notified and arrived on scene at approximately 1830. Hopkins Wrecker Service put down additional dry sweep and absorbent socks. Next, Hopkins used a bobcat to pick up the absorbents, placed them in a lined dumpster, and cleared the soil. A review of the storm water outfall showed zero signs of an oil sheen and no smell was present. There were no off-site impacts from this release. No personnel were harmed and/or injured. At the time of release, the weather was partly cloudy, and the wind was blowing from the south at 8 mph. The temperature was 70F and the humidity was 68%.

item.title: Report I-2025070019
item.description:

  • City: GONZALES

  • Description: On December 2nd , 2024 Driver Manager was called by driver, Eddie Esqueda, and informed that less than 0.5 gallon of Aluminum Sulfate Solution (AL Clear A7 Bulk) overflowed out the top of a customer tank due to a customer aligned, customer system, valve misalignment. The customer acknowledged full responsibility and immediately cleaned up the product. No product left containment and spilled only onto the concrete surrounding the tank. The customer immediately cleaned the small spill up and corrected the valve misalignment to facilitate the continued offloading into the correct customer tank. Driver manager instructed the driver to call and report the incident to Chemtrec to ensure documentation and trigger internal and external reporting of the event. Only when the PHMSA notification was received was the company aware the NRC number had been called and reporting had not been completed.

item.title: Report I-2025060064
item.description:
Report I-2025060064

Identified by scraper @ 2025-07-23T00:58:10+00:00

  • Incident Date: 2024-09-05
  • City: CHANNELVIEW
  • State: TX
  • Report Type: A hazardous material incident
  • Mode Of Transportation: Highway
  • Carrier/Reporter: EQUISTAR CHEMICALS, LP
  • Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Hazmat Injuries: 0
  • Non-Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Total Amount Of Damages: 80000
  • Serious Incident Ind: Yes
  • Description: On September 5, 2024, at around 9:35 AM, approximately 14,200 lbs of Ethyl-aluminum dichloride 15% in Hexane ("EADC" herein) were released from the liquid product discharge valve of a tank trailer during a routine unloading operation at the Product Flexibility Unit Unloading Rack. Infrared hydrocarbon detectors detected the released hexane and automatically activated the area deluge system, which suppressed the hydrocarbon vapors and ultimately washed the material into the process sewer collection system, where it was successfully impounded and neutralized prior to discharging. Site emergency response personnel entered the deluged area and stopped the release by closing the air actuated product discharge valve on top of the tanker, which had been found in the open position and not connected to the unloading boom arm. The investigation identified failed barriers and causes leading to the incident and determined that theloading operator had deviated from the unloading procedure by connecting the pressurizing nitrogen to the tanker and actuating air to the product discharge valve, prior to connecting the product unloading boom arm to the trailer. Emergency response personnel found the pneumatic switch for the air actuated product discharge valve in the "OPEN" position, however, the investigation team was not able to conclusively determine how or why the valve was opened. The pneumatic switch for the valve in the "OPEN" position allowed the pressurized EADC to flow to atmosphere. Following interviews with other qualified EADC unloading operators, the investigation team determined that the individual responsible for unloading this trailer deviated from the well-established unloading procedure used in practice. Corrective actions were generated with the intent of addressing the failed barriers and the underlying causes of these failures. The investigation team concluded that while the loader violated well-established and understood safe unloading procedures, the written language of the EADC unloading procedure is unclear and contains unworkable steps due to the above mentioned out of service system.
